awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Competition and cooperation in the defensive symbiont communities of aphids
awd_abstract_narration:
Insects comprise the bulk of animal diversity on the planet and are often infected with microbes called 'symbionts'. Microbial symbionts can have large effects on their host insects, shaping their interactions with other species or their responses to the non-living environment. This is especially well-studied for plant sap-feeding insects, known as aphids, which can carry various combinations of over ten maternally transferred symbiont species. These symbionts influence aphids' interactions with food plants, protect aphids from attack by parasites and pathogens, or alleviate the effects of temperature changes. Since insects are important vectors of human disease and major agricultural pests, understanding the roles of these 'hidden players', and the mechanisms underlying symbiont function is important to further human interests in crop protection and preventing disease spread. Most studies to date have investigated the effects of single symbiont species infections, even though most insects carry multi-species symbiont 'communities'. This award will use a highly-tractable aphid model system, with well-characterized bacterial symbionts, to identify the effects of competition and cooperation amongst multiple symbionts on symbiont transmission, localization and aphid biology. Researchers will use newly developed culturing methods combined with genomic and gene expression studies, to investigate how these effects are generated. Since maternally transferred symbionts are widespread in insects, findings from the aphid model are relevant to crop and medical pests. In addition, this award supports the training and professional development of high school, undergraduate, graduate and post-doctoral researchers, and includes outreach events into the communities of the investigators.
 
The pea aphid, Acyrthosiphon pisum, harbors a diverse cohort of facultative, maternally transferred symbionts and is an important model for defensive symbiosis. Recent field-based research shows that most individual pea aphids, with a facultative symbiont, harbor two or more species. Interestingly, symbiont distributions are non-random, with enriched co-infection among some symbiont pairs and rare co-infection among others, leading to the prediction that natural selection favors co-infections between symbionts with distinct defensive roles, establishing 'generalist' aphids protected against multiple threats. However, just a subset of such partnerships is likely favored as pairings between rare symbiont partners could heighten costs or emergent pathogenicity. Alternatively, rarity of some co-infections may stem from within-host symbiont interactions, including competition and resulting decreases in transmission rates. Conversely, common co-infections may stem from non-competing, cooperative symbionts that reciprocally enhance transmission. This award will test these different scenarios through manipulative experiments on engineered aphid lines that measure the impacts of co-infection context on symbiont-mediated protective phenotypes and rates of symbiont transfer. Symbiont densities and localization will be linked to aphid fitness, defensive phenotypes, symbiont interactions, and rates of transmission. In addition, genomic and gene-expression analyses of symbionts will be used to identify mechanisms underlying competitive and cooperative dynamics that are predicted to structure pea aphids' symbiont 'communities'. This research will enhance the understanding of multipartite symbioses in insect pests, with implications for mitigating their damage to human health, livestock, agriculture, and infrastructure. It will provide training to high school, undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral students and enhance outreach to the local community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Insect-provided services – e.g. biological control and nutrient cycling –  are critical for natural and managed ecosystems. An exciting theme from modern biology stems from recognition that many such services are mediated by microbial ‘symbionts’. While most symbiotic microbes associate with insect guts, some live within the body cavity and are faithfully transmitted to offspring each generation. These ‘heritable symbionts’ are very common across insects and their relatives. But most have been studied under single infection, despite living in multi-species, heritable symbiont communities.

For this project, we used the pea aphid (Acyrthosiphon pisum) system to disassemble and reassemble simple heritable symbiont communities, and to thereby study the forces that shape their prevalence. Pea aphid symbionts are among the best characterized with respect to function and community composition. Seven facultative symbionts occur in most sampled populations and each symbiont species provides aphids with protection against thermal stress and/or resistance to specific pathogens or parasitic wasps. Our past work had shown that specific symbiont combinations are highly enriched, while others are depleted. Having ruled out a stochastic basis for this ‘community structure’, we took a multifaceted approach to test a range of factors that may drive it.  

Preliminary findings indicated cryptic diversity within our system. We, thus, genotyped thousands of symbionts, finding extensive strain-level variation and that symbiont community is structured at the strain, rather than species level. For example, the most commonly occurring coinfection sampled involved the symbionts Hamiltonella defensa and Fukatsuia symbiotica. While a single strain of Fukatsuia dominated our sampling, strains of Hamiltonella resided in one of five clades (named A- E). In natural populations, Fukatsuia almost always persists as a coinfection, specifically with B-strain Hamiltonella.

Overall, we found that the forces structuring aphid symbiont communities were more complex than originally anticipated, with varying support for all proposed mechanisms depending on the coinfection. The aforementioned Fukatsuia-Hamiltonella B-strain interaction helps to highlight this complexity. First, we considered whether cooperation or competition among symbionts within individual aphids contributed to their frequent pairing. A comparative genomics project revealed that while metabolic complementarity (i.e. cross-feeding cooperation) can explain enrichment of symbiont communities in pea aphids, it does not shape persistence of Fukatsuia and Hamiltonella. This result was consistent with a second genomics project finding that the major difference among Hamiltonella strains involved mobile DNA, rather than chromosomal genes shaping nutrient metabolism. This study identified strain-specific bacteriocins that potentially mediate competition between symbionts and may explain why B Hamiltonella specifically associate with Fukatsuia.

By experimentally breaking apart this focal coinfection into components, we were able to show that Hamiltonella conferred protection against parasitoids in both single and co-infection contexts. Fukatsuia, provided no benefits in either context, but its strong fitness costs under single infection were ameliorated when co-occurring with Hamiltonella. Thus, selection on symbiont-conferred phenotypes explains why coinfections are necessary for Fukatsuia, but not for Hamiltonella. Instead, this was best explained by another study showing that rates of maternal transmission were substantially higher in Hamiltonella-Fukatsuia coinfected aphids relative to those with only Hamiltonella. A combination of selection on symbiont-mediated phenotypes and community-dependent transmission rates, are thus, behind this enriched symbiont pairing. While more speculative, bacteriocin-mediated competition between bacteria within aphids may explain why only B strain Hamiltonella persists with Fukatsuia. 

In this project, we also generated high-resolution genomic detail of the anti-parasitoid symbiont Hamiltonella, finding unexpected strain-level variation in bacterial, phage and toxin genotypes. We further documented repeated transfer of bacteriophage among related Hamiltonella. Our controlled experiments showed this transfer creates symbiont strain protective variability, which correlates with phage virulence factors. Discoveries for turnover in Hamiltonella and APSE-phage strains in natural populations reveal the potential for cyclical antagonistic coevolution, a focus of our ongoing research.

 

Through this award, we also found that the interplay of temperature and parasitism may be major drivers of Hamiltonella dynamics. While most Hamiltonella strains fail to protect under warmer conditions, others are robust. Hamiltonella retaining anti-parasitoid phenotypes under heat appear to also, directly, protect aphids against hot temperatures. Symbiosis may, thus, be a fulcrum in a rapidly warming world due to climate change.

 In summary, this project has significantly advanced a leading model of ecological symbiosis, showing that strain-level variation is often more important than species identify in determining symbiont-conferred phenotypes and symbiont community structure. We identified novel phenotypes conferred by endosymbionts and showed how host-level phenotypes and symbiont transmission vary across community contexts. Persistence of enriched symbiont communities, thus, extends from a complex interplay among forces. This project furthers our understanding of how hidden microbial players contribute to broader ecosystem processes. It substantially contributed to the training and professional development of four graduate researchers, along with many high-school and undergraduate researchers. The work has been disseminated at domestic and international venues, and yielded publication of research articles and book chapters, with additional publications in preparation.
